introduction.p: In the first class of the second semester, some time will be taken to review the course format and syllabus. In the remaining time, work on problems that review some of the fundamental concepts from the first semester.

statement.p: Prove that if f and g are one-to-one functions on a set X, then g \circ f is also a one-to-one function on X. Note: You might be more familiar with the term injection or injective function for a one-to-one function. They all mean the same thing.
Partition the set X=\{k \in \mathbb{Z} \mid -10 \leq k \leq 10\} into equivalence classes according to the relation congruence modulo 4, \equiv_4.
Is the following logical argument valid?

blockquote.p: Peacham is either in Vermont or New Hampshire. If Peacham is in Vermont, then Peacham is in New England. If Peacham is in New Hamphire, then Peacham is in New England. Therefore, Peacham is in New England.

answer.p: Yes, this argument is valid. Symbolically, it is V \lor NH, V\rightarrow NE, NH\rightarrow NE \Rightarrow NE which can be proven correct.

statement.p: Prove, by mathematical induction, that F_0 + F_1 + F_2 + \cdots + F_{n} = F_{n+2} - 1, where F_n is the nth number in the .
Prove that if n is an integer and you divide n^2 by 5, then the remainder is always 0, 1, or 4.
Prove that the square root of 5 is an irrational number.
Solve the recurrence relation e_n=2 e_{n-1}+2^{n-1} with initial condition e_1 = 1. Recall that solving a recurrence relation means finding closed form expression for the sequence it defines.
